Subject: Re: [neat] Self-adaptive Mutation Rates, Novelty Search and CMA-ES
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=LgwrZNxda4MEvcSYV_5dnLXsM2jZL7kKF8ks5GoFboZRuD8xJpGi
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune
From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>


--Apple-Mail=_F59F4744-88B1-47B6-B006-63DB3572095D
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello Vassilis,

Please see below. 

> 
> You ask some interesting question=
s. See below.
> 
>  
> That makes sense. So now my questions are this:
> 1)=
 Do these vectors of standard deviations evolve in the usual sense? I.e. do=
es selection act on the performance on the problem, and the vector of SDs h=
itchhike along for the ride? 
> 
> Yes, since the individuals that pass on =
to the next generation are not comprised only by their usual parameters, bu=
t they contain their strategy parameters as well (SDs).
> 
>  
> 
> 2) Has =
anyone shown that these self-adapted SDs are better than leaving them at a =
fixed size (on rugged fitness landscapes: note that the sphere function is =
not rugged)? I=92d like to see a sweep across different fixed-sizes to find=
 the long-term optimum, and then see if self-adapted SDs outperform the bes=
t of those. My hypothesis is that the self-adaptation is extremely maladapt=
ive (again, provided that the problem is non-trivial). I=92ve asked people =
in the ES community for similar papers, but have never seen one produced. 
=
> 
> I don't come from the field of ES, so I am not sure. I haven't seen su=
ch a paper.

This is always my problem. People, including those in the ES c=
ommunity, *assume* that self-adapting mutation rates are beneficial, but no=
 one ever seems to be able to point me at papers that show that. I=92m not =
blaming you: of course this is not your community. But I=92ve had the same =
conversation many times with people from the ES community and they can=92t =
justify this assumption either=85I find it a bit odd and frustrating: it=92=
s like an urban legend that won=92t die. 

> I noticed though that often pe=
ople benchmark their algorithms on noisy versions of some fitness functions=
 (e.g., a noisy sphere function). Noise creates a kind of rugged landscape,=
 right?
> 
> 

No. I don=92t think so. In fact, noise helps smooth out rugg=
ed landscapes of the long-term, because noise can help you cross a valley (=
by temporarily making the valley seem more fit). 

>  
> 3) If CMA-ES is se=
lf-adapting its mutation rate in a way that helps: why? My paper lays out i=
ntuitive reasons for why we should expect mutation rates to evolve to be lo=
w and hurt long-term performance (because evolution is focusing on the shor=
t-term average fitness, not the long-term average fitness). So why doesn=92=
t this reasoning apply to CMA-ES?
>  
> That is also my understanding of ho=
w it works in tradition ES. But I thought it worked differently in CMA-ES. =
For example, I don=92t think individuals in CMA-ES are mutated versions of =
their parents. I think they are freshly drawn from the learned distribution=
s. And I don=92t think offspring are kept, but are only used to update the =
learned distributions. But as I said, my knowledge of CMA-ES sis fuzzy. Par=
tly because I don=92t understand it perfectly, it=92s hard for me to see if=
 there is some mechanism that allows self-adaptation to work well.  
> 
> I=
n the previous email I was mostly talking about ES. You are right that CMA-=
ES works differently. The mean individual is calculated using weighted reco=
mbination. I don't understand CMA-ES perfectly either, so you've got me thi=
nking. I think now that CMA-ES does not exactly use self-adaptation in the =
normal sense, since it uses something called cumulative step adaptation (CS=
A), also known as cumulative path length control. CSA does not use local mu=
tation steps, but a record of fading mutation steps, known as evolution pat=
h or search path, which carries information about the relation between sing=
le steps.
> 
> I read that this evolution path can improve the adaptation a=
nd search procedure remarkably. Do you think it can be seen as a way to mit=
igate the problem of long-term adaptation?

I don=92t know, because I don=
=92t understand it enough. But at least it sounds like it is trying to inco=
rporate the effect of mutation rates over multiple generations, which is al=
ready an attempt to take a longer-view. My instincts tell me, however, that=
 if it averages over N steps/generations, and N is small (vs. the overall n=
umber of generations in a run), it will still underperform a high-fixed rat=
e. As N goes towards the total number of generations in the run, it will do=
 better=85but that=92s only because it=92s getting rid of self-adaptation a=
nd switching towards fixed mutation rates. 

> 
> So fitness does impact wh=
ich SDs survive? That does sound like self-adaptation, making me skeptical =
about whether it really works. 
> 
> Yes, in self-adaptive ES (not CMA-ES),=
 fitness does impact which SDs survive and selection is deterministic / ran=
k-based.
> 
> 
>  
> Thanks for the clarification. It=92s an interesting, i=
mportant question and I=92m glad we=92re trying to get to the bottom of it.=
 
> 
> In summary, I now think that self-adaptive ES might not perform very=
 well for long-term adaptation, while CSA (which is not the same as self-ad=
aptive mutation rates) is a way to make the algorithm perform better.

Grea=
t. This is how these conversations always go! I keep waiting for someone to=
 say =93oh, here=92s the thing you don=92t understand that explains it all=
=85=94, but instead most people end up agreeing that  (a) self-adaptation d=
oesn=92t work, (b) what they were calling self-adapatation is something els=
e, or (c) stick to the belief that there is lots of evidence that self-adap=
tation does work, but they don=92t know of any specific papers, and tell me=
 I should just go =93read all the old literature=94. I=92m glad that you ar=
e in the (a) and (b) camp! I find the (c) camp a bit frustrating, partly be=
cause I haven=92t had the time to undertake that quest myself=85though I th=
ink I know what the result will be. :0)

Thanks for the interesting discuss=
ion. 

Best,
Jeff



>  
> 
> 
> Best,
> Vassilis
> 
> 
> 

--Apple-Mail=_F59F4744-88B1-47B6-B006-63DB3572095D

Content-Type: text/html;
	charset=windows-1252
